paragraphs.title: Some of the Source Code is From this Book (its a good book for Twitter Scraping/Analysis)
paragraphs.text:
%md ![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/python_social_media.jpg)
- Marco has good topic coverage related to API integration from Twitter and Google ecosystem. - Chapters 1-4 are worth reading, the back end is not - Some other sites that have good API coverage are Pintrest and google + - Also covers web scraping (beautiful soup and selector gadget)

msg.data:
• Marco has good topic coverage related to API integration from Twitter and Google ecosystem.
  • Chapters 1-4 are worth reading, the back end is not
  • Some other sites that have good API coverage are Pintrest and google +
  • Also covers web scraping (beautiful soup and selector gadget)

paragraphs.title: Source Code for Lecture You Are Viewing
paragraphs.text:
%md
![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/github.jpg)

- There is a build file for running this on digital ocean if you would like to set up a droplet
- git clone https://github.com/albre116/SocialMedia.git

msg.data:
• There is a build file for running this on digital ocean if you would like to set up a droplet
  • git clone https://github.com/albre116/SocialMedia.git

paragraphs.title: Housekeeping to Load Libraries and Dependencies
Lets Start by comparing 2 data science pages for influence
We can pull what ever is needed from the API.  Lets start with a home page
paragraphs.text:
%python
from twitter_client import get_twitter_client
import json
client = get_twitter_client()
profile = client.get_user(screen_name="SperDataScience")
print(json.dumps(profile._json, indent =4))

paragraphs.title: Lets get Followers, Timeline, for both pages to compare influence
paragraphs.text:
%sh cd /notebook &&
python /notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_get_user_timeline.py SperDataScience &&
python /notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_get_user_timeline.py BigBytesInfo &&
python /notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_get_user.py SperDataScience &&
python /notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_get_user.py BigBytesInfo

paragraphs.title: So, how did that work???
paragraphs.text:
%md
![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/tfidf.jpg)

- #### The workhorse is the TfidfVectorizer (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer.html)

![](http://lin1pr1ap6:8765/random_images/kmall.png) 

- #### Simple K-Means to form groupings of like feature vectors http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.cluster.KMeans.html

msg.data:
• The workhorse is the TfidfVectorizer (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer.html)

  • Simple K-Means to form groupings of like feature vectors http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.cluster.KMeans.html

root      1431  0.0  0.0  19700  1508 ?        S    01:24   0:00 bash -c ps aux  | grep /notebook/pythonpckg/Chap02_03/twitter_streaming.py

paragraphs.title: kill the running process
Extract Place when available from Stream

paragraphs.text:
%python import folium map_width=1800 map_height=600 map_sf = folium.Map([35, -90], zoom_start=4, tiles='cartodbpositron') import pickle import re # read python dict back from the file pkl_file = open('/notebook/stream__maga.pkl', 'rb') geoItems = pickle.load(pkl_file) pkl_file.close() for k in geoItems['features']: folium.Marker(location = [k['geometry']['coordinates'][1],k['geometry']['coordinates'][0]],popup = re.sub(r'\W+', ' ', k['properties']['text'])).add_to(map_sf) print "%angular " + "
" + map_sf._repr_html_() + "
"
